awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research in Radio/Radar Astronomy and Atmospheric Sciences at Arecibo Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
Arecibo Observatory (AO) will host a summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in Puerto Rico.  Undergraduates from across the country will be guided by AO staff as they complete research projects in radio astronomy, planetary science, atmospheric science, and in the supporting engineering and computing applications.  They will also participate in scientific seminars and professional development programs.  Students from the mainland will be exposed to the Puerto Rican culture and natural history through field trips and social activities.  A special effort will be made to recruit qualified Puerto Rican students, who are underrepresented within STEM fields.  The program includes local science teachers through a Research Experiences for Teachers program.

The main activity for all summer interns is to work on an original research project closely supervised by a staff member. Each participating mentor designs one or more well-defined projects that a student should be able to complete over a ten-week period. Projects may be either self-contained or form a part of a larger endeavor. Observatory staff give an introductory Summer Student Lecture series designed to introduce the students to the fundamental concepts of the science pursued at Arecibo and to the underlying methods employed in their research areas. Throughout the program, science seminars by staff and visiting scientists are also provided to broaden the scientific horizons of the students. As part of their program, students are strongly encouraged to attend a relevant scientific or technical meeting.

por.por_cntn:
The Intellectual Merit of the program lay in the opportunity for the participants to experience the scientific process by conducting novel scientific research, allowing them to explore careers within these fields by participating in front-line research. In addition, the participants' knowledge base expanded through an associated cross-discipline lecture course, which includes lectures on Puerto Rican geology, culture, and history along with career advice and professional development. Many REU projects also lead to publications in peer reviewed journals, although often with a lead time of few years.

The Broader Impact of this program was the creation and expansion of a scientific mindset within members of the undergraduate and local teaching communities. Our program was strengthened by the multi-disciplinary research conducted at the observatory that spans from our atmosphere, through the solar system, and beyond to other galaxies. The program enhanced the diversity by taking students from underrepresented minorities and smaller universities and colleges. Over the last three years we havr tripled the number of Hispanic undergraduate students from Puerto Rican universities on our REU program and we aim to continue this success. This year we aimed in particular to increase our recruitment of women students from underrepresented minorities.

The outcomes of this year can be summarize in:

1) We were able to conduct an in-person experience for the students even with the COVID-19 pandemic and the collapse of the radio-telescope

2) The students were able to discover the culture and wonders of Puerto Rico, while conducting a high quality research. 

3) The participants name, university and title of their projects in presented below: 

Courteney S. Monchinski - University of Colorado, Boulder

Characterization of Asteroid 52768 (1998 OR2)

 

Emma P. Lieb - University of Colorado- Boulder 

Searching for Pulsars at the Arecibo Observatory

 

Leo Skaer- Agnes Scott College 

Velocity Distribution of Millisecond Pulsars

 

Pranav Nalamwar- Michigan State University

Estimation of Ion Composition in Descending Layers over Arecibo

 

Victoria G. Wright- Auburn University

Effects of Geomagnetic Storms on Earth’s Ionosphere over Arecibo

 

Dariel J. Vidal-Cotto- Inter American University of Puerto Rico- Bayamón Campus

The Culebra Aerosol Research Lidar (CARLA) project WEB PAGE

 

Gabriel A. Colón-Sánchez- University of Puerto Rico- Mayagüez Campus

 Development of a Prototype for a Web-Based Portfolio Utility

for AO Users

 

Gaddiel Ayala-Monges (RET)

Teacher at Robinson School
